bioghist.p: The Cadburys are a prominent Quaker family in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Sarah Cadbury (1840-1918) was the daughter of Joel Cadbury (1799-1870) and Caroline Warder Cadbury (1801-1868). She was a member of the House of Industry of the Female Society of Philadelphia for the Relief and Employment of the Poor. John (Jack) Cadbury (b.1912) was the son of John Warder Cadbury (1880-1948) and Rachel Comfort (Reeve) Cadbury (1880-1969). He studied at Earlham College and graduated from Cornell in 1936. During World War II he worked with the Friends War Victims Relief Committee assisting with Friends work in England.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to the Cadbury family. Materials include: letters from the Hack family to Sarah Cadbury describing Quaker relief work in France after the siege of Metz (1870-1871); letters to and from John (Jack) Cadbury while he was in England working for the Friends War Victims Relief Committee (1941-1947); Cadbury, Head, Warder, Foulke, and Gibbins family genealogical records, including pedigrees, family histories, and family photographs; a scrapbook of clippings and watercolors from the 1840s; and a typescript copy of Edward Manice's thesis "George Fox, Quakers, Negroes and Slavery on Barbados, 1671-1675." The collection also includes photographs of the Brown and Bacon families, an account book (1856-1857) of Joseph Philbrook, shoemaker (also includes accounts of the South China Mechanics Association), and plates of silhouettes mounted on wood blocks.
